title: The online shopping fraud you may not know about | The Business | ABC NEWS
description: Shoplifting has long been the bane of small businesses and now the theft has moved online, with frustrated owners telling business reporter Adelaide Miller they have lost thousands of dollars to fraudulent chargebacks — that is, online shoppers disputing legitimate transactions and receiving a refund. The fake refund claims, instigated by shoppers requesting chargebacks through their banks, have been labelled theft. Online fashion store owner Sam Kemp posted a video to Instagram about her experience that went viral. She says she's received hundreds of messages from other small business owners, who have had the same thing happen to them.   Sydney fashion boutique owner Ainslie says she has lost thousands of dollars to chargebacks in recent months, and has had little success convincing banks not to take back the money after purchasers falsely disputed charges on their credit card.  Despite retailers presenting evidence that items were ordered and delivered, some have had transactions cancelled, leaving them without the money or the stock. The frustrated small business owners are now calling for greater protection.   The Australian Banking Association told the ABC it's aware of fraudulent chargeback concerns from small businesses and where possible banks will work with them to resolve  disputes, but it has to fall within the card network provider's timeframes and rules. Mastercard didn't comment but Visa said it had "introduced rules allowing businesses to use historical purchasing data to fight 'friendly fraud'. This is designed to protect businesses from repeat chargeback abuse." Payments expert Brad Kelly said one of the reasons small businesses may be unsuccessful in disputing fraudulent chargebacks could be the "sheer volume" occurring.  #ABCBusiness Subscribe: http://ab.co/1svxLVE   ABC NEWS provides around the clock coverage of news events as they break in Australia and abroad. title: Housing approvals fell sharply in October, despite the worsening shortage | Finance Report
description: House prices increased 1% in November, while approvals for new dwellings fell 6.4% in October. That's about two thirds of the number of places per month needed to meet the national housing accord target of 1.2 million in five years. Meanwhile, cryptocurrency prices continued to come under pressure, while global stocks fell and bond yields rose overnight. title: Military in the spotlight over its handling of sexual violence in its ranks | ABC NEWS
description: A landmark inquiry into sexual violence in the defence force will be held next year to try to address what the federal government says is a "scourge" on the organisation. It's not the first time the issue has been brought to the forefront. The Royal Commission into Defence and Veteran Suicide uncovered "extensive" evidence of sexual assaults. Political reporter Laura Lavelle explains. title: The government's AI plan falls well short of keeping Australians safe, says AI expert | The Business
description: The federal government has laid out its road map to accelerate the development and adoption of AI, accepting demands from business to pause mandatory guardrails, which had been intended to operate under a standalone AI act to protect Australians from potential harms. Co-director of the UTS Human Technology Institute, Professor Nicholas Davis says the government's artificial intelligence plan falls well short when it comes to keeping Australians safe. He says a commitment from the government to protect Australians isn't enough. "What's important is that the government puts that on the legislative agenda," he says. "I think first off the rank as it were, should be privacy." He says Australia's data protection and privacy rules are "woefully out of date" compared to the rest of the world. He's calling for the government to legislate protections for online safety, privacy, and protections for children. #ABCBusiness Subscribe: http://ab.co/1svxLVE  ABC NEWS provides around the clock coverage of news events as they break in Australia and abroad. title: Singapore-based firm scraps controversial luxury hotel planned for Darwin Waterfront | ABC NEWS
description: An 11-storey, $100 million luxury hotel proposed for the Darwin Waterfront has fallen through, following concerns the project would overlook a traditional Aboriginal sacred site.  The development of the high-rise hotel was announced in 2024, with the NT government touting it as a major boost for Darwin that would offer jobs, tourism and upscale accommodation.  Sam Parry has this story for ABC News Northern Territory. title: Filmmaker breaks decades of silence over Yolŋu clan leader's alleged murder by police | ABC NEWS
description: Earlier this year we brought you an investigation into the mysterious disappearance and suspected murder in 1934 of Yolngu clan leader Dhakiyarr Wirrpanda, with our reporter unearthing new information about a policeman believed to have murdered him   After seeing our story, a celebrated film maker called us, and has broken four decades of silence to reveal shocking new eyewitness testimony backing the claim.  And a warning for Aboriginal and Torres Strait islander viewers - this story features images of people who have died. Jason Walls has this report for ABC News Northern Territory. description: Clashes have erupted on the border between Peru and Chile as tensions escalate over new restrictions that prevent undocumented people from crossing over.
